subject: OT (that's OK): Class design (Re: [junit] Use of final and private)
msgSnippet: Kris Henderson wrote:  ... I don t like Helper . Helpers feel procedural. I prefer Strategies. Maybe the private methods are a way to do X, so they
messageBody:
Kris Henderson wrote:

<snip />

> Now after JUnit testing for awhile
> my classes are starting to look kind of like this:
>
> class MyNiftyClass
> MyNiftyClass(NiftyHelper helper);
> public SomeReturnValue doSomethingNifty();
> public AnotherReturnValue doSomethingElseNifty();
>
> class NiftyHelper
> NiftyHelper()
> public int aPrivateMethod(int param1, int param2);
> public String anotherPrivateMethod(String param);
>
> Now all the methods are public and easy to test.
>
> What does everyone think? Is this a good way to organize the classes?

I don't like "Helper". Helpers feel procedural. I prefer Strategies.
Maybe the private methods are a way to do X, so they are strategies for
which I can extract a useful interface for doing X in general, then
depend on that interface.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
